text: Andrée Dumon also written as Andrée Dumont (5 September 1922 – 30 January 2025) was a Belgian resistance fighter during World War II.Escape or die: The untold WWII story, Daily Mail, 16 March 2007 She was a member of the Comet Line network, which helped Allied pilots who had been shot down over enemy territory to return to England via France and Spain. After being betrayed, she was arrested and deported to Ravensbrück concentration camp and finally Mauthausen concentration camp. She was liberated there in April 1945.Edward Stourton, Cruel Crossing: Escaping Hitler Across the Pyrenees, Random House, 2013.Sherri Greene Ottis: Silent Heroes: Downed Airmen and the French Underground. University Press of Kentucky, 2001Dailymail, John Nicol and Tony Renell, 19 March 2007: A terrible betrayal that haunts British airmen to this day: The untold WWII story. Gearchiveerd, 22 April 2021. After many decades of silence, she decided during the 1990s to testify to young people and the general public about her war years. Dumon died in on 30 January 2025, at the age of 102. ==References== Category:Belgian people of World War II Category:World War II resistance members Category:Belgian centenarians Category:1922 births Category:2025 deaths Category:People from Brussels Category:Place of death missing
